DOC.HEAD: Argentina, Britain Resume Consular Relations
DOC.TEXT: Argentina and Britain resumed consular ties on Thursday after a nearly eight-year gap that dated back to the Falkland Islands War. Alan Hunt presented his credentials to the Foreign Ministry and was accepted as Britain's consul. A similar ceremony took place in London, where Santos Goni was accredited as the Argentine consul. Since the 1982 war, which Argentina launched to recover territory in the South Atlantic it has claimed since the last century, each country has maintained only an interest section in the other: Argentina at Brazil's embassy in London, Britain at the Swiss Embassy in Buenos Aires. Consular flags will be hoisted in London and Buenos Aires on Friday. The way was paved for a thaw in relations by the election of Carlos Menem as Argentina's president last May. Menem dropped the government's previous insistence that ownership of the Falklands be an issue in any bilateral talks. The countries have agreed to resume air and maritime communications and lift all remaining commercial and financial restrictions and restrictive practices imposed since 1982. They also agreed to an umbrella clause that protects their respective claims to sovereignty over the islands, which are inhabited by 1,800 people, mostly British descendants. A further meeting in February is expected to lead to resumption of full diplomatic relations. Buenos Aires surrendered to a British task force on June 14, 1982, 74 days after invading the South Atlantic archipelago.
